loans.name: Sara Giovanna

texts.es:
SARA GIOVANNA SEPULVADA O., pertenece al Banco Comunal “MUJERES SHIPIBAS, tiene 35 años de edad, 4 hijos, y su pareja es maderero.

Con el primer préstamo de S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, se inició en el negocio de venta de frutas.  Compró diversas frutas para vender y poder solventar los gastos familiares.

Hoy, ella ha progresado con su familia y el negocio de su esposo ha mejorado.  Con este préstamo de S/. 1,800.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará más mercaderías para vender (frutas de la zona al por mayor).

“Manuela Ramos es una ONG que apoya a una gran cantidad de familias, con pequeños préstamos que permite a las mujeres de esta zona a iniciar o a mejorar sus negocios.  Estoy contenta con esa ayuda” refirió.
texts.en:
Sara Giovanna Sepulvada O. belongs to the "Mujeres Shipibas" Communal Bank. She is 35 years old and has four children. Her husband sells lumber. With her first loan for S/.300, she started a business selling fruit. She bought a variety of fruit to offer and was able to cover family expenses. Since then her family has made progress, and her husband's business has improved. With this loan for S/.1,800, she will buy more fruit (from the wholesale market). "The Manuela Ramos NGO supports many families through small loans that allow women in this region to start businesses or improve them. I am happy with their help," she says.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly Wester, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of wholesale fruit

loans.name: Akuvi

texts.fr: Akuvi S. est productrice de l’huile de palme à Wome. Agée de 46 ans, elle est mariée et mère de  3 enfants. cette activité est est sa principale source de revenus et elle en fait une bonne gestion. Avec ce crédit, Akuvi souhaite acheter des matières premières notamment des noix de palme afin d’augmenter sa production et par conséquent ses revenus.
texts.en:
Akuvi S. produces palm oil in Wome. She is 46 years old, married, and the mother of 3 children. This business is her principal source of revenue and she runs it well. With this loan, Akuvi wishes to buy raw materials, notably palm nuts, so as to increase her production and thus her income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing palm nuts for producing palm oil

loans.name: Ana

texts.es: Ana tiene 37 años, hace 10 años vive con su pareja y padre de su hija en el terreno que adquirió, donde vienen construyendo su casa propia para brindar a su hija las mejores condiciones de vida. Desde que asumió la responsabilidad de ser esposa y madre buscó la forma de generar más ingresos, gracias al apoyo de su hermana incursionó en la venta de cosméticos hace 5 años, primero la apoyó en las ventas, pero poco a poco se independizó debido a la gran cantidad de clientes que había logrado conseguir. Ahora se asoció con su hermana para la elaboración de collares artesanales que realizan en su casa para luego venderlos en las ferias del distrito y a la vez dictan clases de bisutería en algunos colegios. Ana se siente muy bien, pues enseñar es uno de sus dones, de la misma forma, trata que cada entorno social sea una oportunidad de buscar a personas que puedan convertirse en clientes potenciales para su negocio. Su más grande sueño es tener una empresa de joyas junto a su hermana. Su permanecía en Microfinanzas PRISMA es de 3 años, está en el su 5to préstamo y durante  estos años, junto a su grupo, ha tratado de trabajar organizadamente y con mucha responsabilidad a favor de todos. Los 1000 soles que solicita los invertirá en la compra de más productos de belleza y materiales para la elaboración de sus collares.
texts.en:
Ana is 37 years old and has lived with her partner, the father of her daughter, for the past 10 years on the land they bought. They are building their own house to give their daughter a better standard of living. Ever since she has taken on the responsibility of wife and mother, she has looked for ways to generate more income. Thanks to the support of her sister, she started with cosmetic sales 5 years ago. First she helped with the sales but little by little she became independent thanks to the large number of customers she had made. Now she has gone into partnership with her sister. They make hand-made necklaces at home to later sell at the district fairs. At the same time they teach jewelry making in some schools. Ana is very happy since she is gifted at teaching. In the same way, she tries to turn every social setting into an opportunity to look for people who could turn into potential customers for her business. Her biggest dream is to have a jewelry business with her sister. She has been with Microfinanzas PRISMA for 3 years. She is on her 5th loan. During these years with her group she has tried to work in an organized and responsible way for all. She will invest the 1000 PEN she is applying for to purchase more beauty products and supplies to make her necklaces.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Gulsinoy

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

Ашурова Гулсиной – женщина 1963 года рождения, замужем, имеет 3-х детей. Продаёт  детскую одежду на вещевом рынке Джаббор-Расуловского района. Два раза в неделю Гулсиной вместе с соседями по бизнесу ездят в город Истаравшан за товаром.  На полученный кредит она хочет расширить свой ассортимент за счет летней одежды, и тем самым поднять свой товарооборот. Её товары пользуются большим спросом среди покупателей,  так как она привозит качественную и красочную детскую одежду  по доступным  для населения  ценам. Гулсиной  рада сотрудничеству с нашей организацией.
texts.en:
Born in 1963, Gulsinoy A. is married and has 3 children. She sells children’s clothing at the clothing market in the Jabbor-Rasulov district. Twice per week, Gulsinoy and her business neighbors travel to the city of Istaravshan for their merchandise. She wants to use this loan to expand her assortment by buying summer clothing and, thus, increase her goods turnover. Her merchandise is in high demand among her customers because she sells beautiful, quality children’s clothing at affordable prices. Gulsinoy is happy to be working with our organization.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of summer children's clothing

loans.name: Jose Antonio

texts.es:
El señor José Antonio vive solamente con su esposa la señora Francisca Amador, son una pareja muy unida y establecida. 
El señor se dedica a la elaboración y venta de barbacoa, todos los días sábados y domingos sobre pedido, negocio que tiene desde hace 16 años; también se encarga de la repartición  de una panadería en las diferentes tiendas de venta desde hace 8 años. 
Don José es una persona emprendedora y con una gran visión de salir adelante, ya que no solamente tiene estos ingresos sino que cuenta con ingresos extras mediante la venta por temporada de bolis, paletas de hielo etc. 
Y el motivo por el cual están solicitando este crédito es para la inversión en diferentes productos para su venta de temporada.
texts.en:
Sr. José Antonio and his wife, Sra. Francisca Amador, live by themselves. They are a united and well-established couple.

Don José sells barbecue every Saturday and Sunday by request. He has been in this line of business for 16 years. He is also in charge of distribution for a bakery that services different retail shops, a position he has held for 8 years.

Don José is a hard worker and has ambitious plans to get ahead. Not only does he want to maintain his current income, he wants to earn some extra money through a seasonal business selling Bolis (a Mexican brand of ice cream treats), crates of ice, and other frozen items. He is requesting a loan so that he can sell these seasonal products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in a new business selling frozen treats

loans.name: Maricor

texts.en:
Maricor is the 40-year-old mother to Ezra who is five years old. She lives in Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is married to Roel who is 31 years old and is a jeepney (small bus) driver. She believes that poverty is not a hindrance to success, it is in the person to strive hard to reach her dreams.

In 2007, Maricor joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, hoping that she could have access to capital for her business retailing rice, charcoal and chickens. She been running the business for three years already and she is happy that she receives enough profit from it.

Now on her 3rd loan, Maricor requests the amount of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for sixty sacks of charcoal, five sacks of rice, and live chickens, all for resale.

With the opportunity and trust given to her by ASHI and Kiva, Maricor believes that she can reach her dream for her children, to send them to school and to expand her business. She is looking forward to having a space in the market for her business.

loans.use: To pay for 60 sacks of charcoal, 5 sacks of rice, and live chickens

loans.name: Kweku

texts.en: Kweku is a 34-year-old married father of two children, who are currently in school. Kweku sells used jeans and khaki trousers on a pavement in Kasoa. Kweku has been selling for five years to support his household, and he says that selling jeans, khaki trousers and knickers, especially for men, is very profitable. With his loan, Kweku wants to buy bales of jeans, khaki trousers and knickers to increase his inventory and sales and earn good income. He believes this loan will help him save more money to rent a store since selling on pavements is not safe.

loans.use: To buy bales of used jeans, khaki trousers and knickers

loans.name: Juan José

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua, el señor Juan A. B. se dedica a su actividad de venta de verduras las que son comercializadas por él mismo todos los días desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana hasta el atardecer.

Es de importancia destacar que el señor A. es muy visitado por los clientes y por ello debe de mantener sus estantes listos para la venta de las verduras y de esta manera continuar con su negocio en su localidad.

loans.use: Compra de las verduras

loans.name: Belice Del Carmen

texts.es: Belice de 31 años de edad es casada, tiene una bebita de 8 meses de edad, trabaja para el MINSA como coordinadora del programa psicologa de salud desde hace 9 años, cuenta con ela apoyo de su esposo quien asume los gastos del hogar, esta solicitando su 6to credito para seguir mejorando su vivienda, pues con los creditos anteriores ha logrado construir su casa, la cual aun no habita porque no tiene instalado el sistema electrico, por lo que esta solicitando el credito, necesita comprar los alambres, lamparas, y otras cosas necesarias para el buen funcionamiento de la energia, ademas desea poder pintar su casa para que tenga una buena presentacion y se vea bonita, pues desea que su pequeña hija se desarrolle en un ambiente agradable.  El mayor sueño de Belice es poder terminar su casa y darle buenas condiciones de vida a su hija que es el mayor tesoro que posee.
texts.en:
Thirty-one-year-old Belice is married and has a baby eight months old. She has worked for MINSA as coordinator of the mental health program for the last 9 years. She depends on her husband's help with household expenses. She is requesting her sixth loan to continue improving her house. With previous loans, she has been able to build her house, although the house is not occupied because the electrical system is not installed. Hence, she is requesting this loan and needs to buy wiring, lamps, and other things necessary for the proper functioning of the electrical system. In addition, she wants to be able to paint the house so that it looks good and is attractive. She wants her little girl to grow up in a pleasant environment. The primary dream of Belice is to finish her house and give good living conditions to her daughter, who is the greatest treasure she possesses.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installation of electrical system and painting of house

loans.name: Awat

texts.en: Awat E. is currently in the business of selling clothes and bedsheets and is requesting a loan to purchase a sewing machine.  Awat is 34 years old and is Divorced.   She has 1 child and her child goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a hotel at the nearby market BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Bola

texts.en: Bola is 42 years old and married with four children. She sells crates of drinks both wholesale and retail to her customers to make a living. She hopes for the loan of N170,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Jeremias

texts.pt:
Jeremias N., nasceu em Manjacaze, província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, tem 32 anos de idade, casado e pai de 8 filhos de 11,10,8,7,5,5,1,1 anos de idade, destes 6 vão a escola. Fez somente 4ªclasse porque os pais não dispunham de meios financeiros para dar continuidade. Vive com a família, na casa própria em Mahelane, Distrito de Namaacha, fronteira com a Suazilândia e sustenta sua Mãe enviando algum valor monetário.

Saiu de Manjacaze para Namaacha no tempo da Guerra de destabilização com os seus pais. Iniciou a activdade comercial e de pesca para fazer face a situação difícil de vida que encarava com a família. Trabalha sozinho com a mulher, que tem ajudado quando o marido estiver ausente. Tem um rendimento de cerca de 4.000.00mt a 5.000.00mt por mês e poupa algum através de sistema de poupança tradicional (Xitique).

Nunca solicitou empréstimos em outras instituições de crédito, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu vizinho que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o 2º empréstimo com a Hluvuku, no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos de mercearia e refrigerantes (cerveja, refrescos, vinhos e outros). O empréstimo passado foi de 15.500.00mt para a mesma actividade.

O objectivo principal com o empréstimo, é de satisfazer o mercado e diversificar o produto no seu estabelecimento. Compromete se a pagar devidamente este crédito para poder aceder a mais empréstimos no futuro para poder construir dependências de aluguer.
texts.en:
Jeremias N. was born in Manjacaze, Gaza province, south of Mozambique. He is 32 years old, married and the father of 8 children ages 11, 10, 8, 7, 5, 5, 1 and 1, six of them go to school. He finished 6th grade but had to drop school because of his parents financial difficulties. He lives with his family in their own house and supports his mother sending her money every month. He owns a store and with the help of his wife he makes between $130 and $170 per month. He is asking for U$525 in order to buy more food products and beverages (beer, wine and soft drinks) to seel at his store. He hopes to diversify his business and increase the sales by adding new products to his store. He plans on paying the loan on time so he can ask for another loan in the future in order to build properties to rent out.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of beverages and food products for reselling

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
Adama J. (right) is a hairdresser who owns a beauty salon in Magburaka town. She is 27 years old and single with one child who is in class I. Adama was born in Magburaka town. She has been in her profession for ten years now. She will invest her share of the loan in hair and cosmetics.

Adama is the leader of the United Sisters Group. They are small-scale business people from Magburaka town, Northern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of 1,500,000 leones (SLL) (500,000 SLL each) for the first time to to expand and improve their businesses. With more goods in their shops/stalls, they will be able to attract a lot of customers, make more sales and increase their profit margin. Consequently, they will be able to better look after themselves and their children.

loans.use: To buy hair and cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizers and expand her arable area

loans.name: Jovelie

texts.en: Jovelie married at an early age. She is still only 20 years old, married for three years and has two kids. She is involved in rice farming. She also manages a sari-sari (variety) store. Her husband is also a barber and has his own shop. Jovelie shares that she is happy to have the businesses her family has. She wants to maintain them and save for her children’s future. She also mentioned that she still needs additional capital for their farm. The farm is being prepared for planting and it needs farm inputs. She applied to CEVI and asked for a loan of Php 9,000, which will be used to finance the farm. This loan will help sustain Jovelie’s rice farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Salesio

texts.en:
Salesio is married to Wanjiru and they have three children: Cynthia, David and Mercy.

Salesio was introduced to KADET through existing clients and he is servicing his first loan. He has never borrowed from another Micro-Finance Institution before. Salesio has been in the secondhand shoes supply business for seven years. He intends to use the loan to purchase shoes from other external markets.

Salesio's field of business is highly competitive, and the client relies on plastic manufacturing companies who acquire the secondhand shoe soles for raw materials. This ensures that his secondhand shoes are sold either way; i.e., to be worn as a good shoe or to have the soles reused. 

With the extra profits that result from this loan, Salesio shall further educate his children as well as increase the number of the rental houses that he has. The rental houses make up his secondary income source.

Salesio hopes to own a permanent building for rental houses, as he believes he is focused and hardworking.

loans.use: to add stock of secondhand shoes

loans.name: Mugandu Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
N. David is the leader of his lending group in Kihihi. He is 28 years old and married with one child only one year old.

David is a businessman involved in agriculture. He keeps animals for meat and for sale and the challenge he has is that animal vaccines are in short supply and hence more expensive.

David has operated from Kyogo – Kinaaba village for two years and he is able to make 20,000/= as profits every week. He hopes to continue having high quality breeds of animals so that his standard of living will improve. He also hopes to have a family motorcycle to help with transport.

David mostly trades and rears goats and he hopes his first loan will help him increase his income and foster business growth. He is such a social and hardworking man and needs a loan to be able to buy more goats.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell

loans.name: Jovelyn's Group

texts.en:
Jovelyn F. is from the village of Benito Soliven. She is 30 years old. Jovelyn is the leader of a 8-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jovelyn F..

Jovelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovelyn owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Jovelyn has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jovelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to expand her business. Jovelyn is requesting a new loan of 45000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Jovelyn's fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Women In Need Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the 'Women in Need' group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 each to enable them to add more goods to their business inventories. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and better profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding and clothing and in their academic pursuits. 

Sallay C. (pictured 3rd from left) is the leader of this group. She is approximately 40 years old. She was born in Makeni and is married with 5 children. 3 of her children are attending secondary school and 2 in primary school. For many years now, Sallay has been selling rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With her share of the loan, Sallay will buy bags of rice and gallons of palm oil to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and gallons of palm oil for resale

loans.name: Osmar Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Osmar Antonio C. es trabajador de  la alcaldía de Chinandega, desempeña el cargo de vigilante, es acompañado con dos hijos en edades escolares, su compañera es ama de casa, pero también muy luchadora para salir adelante con la ayuda de Dios.
El señor C. habita en San José del Obraje, aparte de trabajar para la Alcaldía se dedica a la  Agricultura  
Lleva 6 créditos con ceprodel, y ha demostrado ser muy responsable
texts.en:
Osmar works as a security guard for the city of Chinandega. He has two school-aged children. His wife works as a housekeeper, but she also works hard to get ahead with God’s help. Osmar lives in San José del Obraje. Besides working for the city, he is also a farmer. He has had six loans through Ceprodel and he has demonstrated great responsibility.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building materials

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: To make a living, Virginia B. owns and operates a business venture preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She is 43 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of San Mateo. Virginia has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Virginia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her sixth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Norn

texts.en:
Mrs. Norn P. (in the photo), 45, and her husband, Mr. Phearom Ream, 52, have been married since 1986 and have three children: two sons who attend school and one daughter who weaves silk at home. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Norn has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a farmer. She is asking for a loan of US$ 600 to purchase silk materials for her and her daughter’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Deelika

texts.en:
Deelika is a 28-year-old married woman living with her husband and one child in Hikkaduwa, southern Sri Lanka.

Deelika and her husband manage and run a fish-selling business in their village. The income they receive from the business helps to pay the family's day-to-day expenses. They started this fish-selling business fifteen years ago, and the income it has provided has helped to educate their child, on top of paying daily expenses.

Deelika is a very hard worker and helps out other members in the village whenever the opportunity arises.

Deelika is asking for a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help expand her business. Her business has a good location within the village and her business has lots of fish, which she hopes to expand with the help of this loan. Her customer base seems to be growing so she hopes this loan will help her expand further.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy some materials for her fish-selling business

loans.name: Atef

texts.en:
Atef is a 49-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife. He has been working in the construction industry for 27 years. He specializes in placing the concrete foundation in walls, which takes place before other siding or paint is applied. He has been running his own business since 1990. He says that he has faced some challenge in securing sufficient financing for his business. 

He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner. He plans to use the loan to invest in a mode of transportation for his business. He believes the loan will have a positive impact on his business and increase his income, which will help him better support his family.

loans.use: To invest in a mode of transportation for his business

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel C. is from the town of Banga. He is 60 years old. Manuel is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Manuel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Manuel has been engaged in his business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Manuel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manuel is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Manuel from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of herbicides, expand her farmable land and the purchase of fertilizer.

loans.name: Rukhsana Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana bibi lives in the city of Vehari in Pakistan with her family. Her husband works in a mill while her son is a hairdresser and runs a barber shop in the market. His father also helps him upon return from his own job. Rukhsana is a housewife. She manages the domestic chores, takes care of her family and prepares food for them. Her other three children are getting their education.

Rukhsana is applying for a loan from Asasah to assist her son, who wants to improve his barber shop by installing chairs and mirrors and buying hair color, creams and shampoos. She hopes that by making an investment in his business, his income will be increased and he will be able to have a better financial life.

loans.use: to purchase required items for the barber shop

loans.name: Rosa Pepita

texts.es:
Rosa de 47 años, vive en el Suburbio de Guayaquil(zona urbana, la mayoría de habitantes son comerciantes informales), ella tiene un pequeño restaurante, hace comidas típicas como seco de chivo, pollo y carne. 

Uno de sus hijos la motivo a que dejara de cocinar en su casa y se pusiera su propio negocio de comidas, comenzó haciendo platos típicos poco a poco invirtió dinero para comprar una cocina industrial, por esa buena decisión ella ahora tiene un pequeño restaurante hace almuerzos y meriendas, trabaja desde las 16h00 hasta las 22:00pm todos los días. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar bebidas y arroz para sus comidas, en el futuro quiere tener un local y trabaja con mas personas.
texts.en:
Rosa, who is 47 years old, lives in the Suburbio de Guayaquil (an urban area; the majority of inhabitants are small business owners). She has a small restaurant where she makes typical foods like braised goat stew, chicken stew and beef stew. One of her children urged her to stop cooking in her house and start her own food business. She began by making typical dishes and little by little invested the money to buy an industrial kitchen. Because of this good decision she now has a small restaurant where she makes meals and snacks. She works from 4:00 pm until 10:00 pm everyday. Rosa wants to use the loan to buy drinks and rice for her foods. In the future, she wants to have a larger restaurant and work with more people.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Drinks, rice

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa C. lives in the village of Bayabo East. She is 46 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business where she sells fish to people who live in her community. She has been in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from her work.

In 2009, Elisa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP. She used that loan to repair a vehicle she uses in her work, and now is applying for a new loan, for 7,000 PHP, to buy additional products to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to continue expanding and improving her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Dosbol

texts.en:
Dosbol D. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger--a traditional nomadic housing tent--in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. His elder two children attend a local middle school and the youngest son goes to a local kindergarten. His wife takes care of their children.

Dosbol operates a taxi service between the countryside and the capital of the province. He started his business in 1992 and after several years in business, he was able to afford to buy a larger, more reliable automobile. But the van he has purchased was a disadvantageous one that  requires too much petrol which has made it hard for him to manage his business successfully and make a profit. 

Dosbol is still operating his transportation business  but supplements his  service earnings by transporting raw materials such as sheepskins, goat skins and wool and coal from the countryside to the province center. He works very hard to provide for his family. He says, “My only wish is to support my children's education and have them become good people.” 

Dosbol is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase tires for his automobile and a large amount of coal for his business.

loans.use: To purchase tires for his automobile and coal to transport

loans.name: Siti

texts.en:
Siti is married to a businessman and has six children; five attend school and one is still too young for school. She has been operating a retail shop and green vegetable stall for over ten years.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

Her potential customers are the neighboring community. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. Siti's major goal is to open another retail shop in the future.

She decided to work with Yehu because of its sustainable financial services. She lives in her own house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane H. is from the village of Malasin, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 33 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns and operates a general store selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Mary Jane joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her third from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

location.town: Malasin Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Nicolas N. is from the town of Banga. He grows corn crops and manages a piggery business. Nicolas has been engaged in his business for quite a long time now. He hopes to have a stable income.

Nicolas joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation. He has two children and he does his best to provide for all their needs. 

Nicolas has applied for a loan of 15,000 PHP. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies and feed for the pigs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase rice, beverages

loans.name: Sorbeh Traders Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the “Sorbeh Traders” group from the northern city of Makeni. They are petty traders who have applied for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each in order to expand their businesses. With the help of this loan, these petty traders will be able to add more goods to their businesses so that sales will increase. In this way, they can easily repay the loan and better look after themselves and their children. 

The leader of this group is Isatu K.. The 43-year-old sells market food – rice and palm-oil. She has been in this business for many years now. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business by buying rice and palm oil in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy rice and palm oil in large quantity

loans.name: Betty Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Betty A. A. es una emprendedora ama de casa que vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos en el municipio de San Juan De Nepomuceno, un pintoresco pueblo enclavado en las serranías del departamento de Bolívar, al norte de Colombia y famoso por sus artesanías. En la actualidad ella se dedica a vender mercancías como: blusas, camisas, pantalones, faldas, jeans para hombres y mujeres, calzado, perfumes, aretes, pulseras y accesorios femeninos. El negocio comenzó hace dos años cuando a raíz del incremento en los gastos familiares, debido especialmente a la educación de los hijos, y a las dificultades del hogar para aumentar los ingresos, la microempresaria consiguió un pequeño préstamo con un familiar, viajó a Cartagena, la más importante ciudad turística de Colombia y compró algunos pocos productos que llevó a su pueblo natal. El éxito en las ventas fue total. Repartió la mercancía entre vecinos, amigos, familiares y referidos a quienes le exigía una cuota inicial y les concedía un plazo de hasta 45 días para cancelar el saldo. La clientela y los pedidos empezaron a crecer. Hoy con satisfacción la señora Betty dice que le ayuda a su esposo con los gastos familiares sin descuidar sus obligaciones de madre y esposa porque su negocio no le ocupa todo el tiempo. El margen promedio de utilidad que le genera su actividad es en promedio del 38%. Este es el primer crédito que tramita con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para invertirlo en la compra  de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños, calzado, perfumes y accesorios femeninos. Por la proximidad de la temporada decembrina, los pedidos se han incrementado sustancialmente. Con el paso del tiempo, la microempresaria ha logrado consolidar una buena clientela y ha descartado aquellos que le quedaron morosos. Sueña en un futuro no muy lejano abrir un almacén en el que pueda ofrecer todos sus productos y atender más cómodamente a todo el que la visite.
texts.en:
Betty A. A. is an entrepreneurial homemaker that lives with her husband and three children in the San Juan de Nepomuceno municipality located in the hills of Bolivar in northern Colombia, , a picturesque village famous for its artisanal crafts.

Currently she sells merchandise like blouses, shirts, pants, skirts, jeans, footwear, perfume, earrings, bracelets and women’s accessories.  The business started years ago when, due to an increase in family expenditures, mainly because of the children’s education and other household difficulties.  This small business owner got a small loan from a family member, traveled to Cartagena, the most important tourist city in Colombia, and bought some products that she brought to her hometown.

She had total sales success.  She sold the merchandise to neighbors, friends, family and those that were referred to her.  She required a down payment and gave them up to 45 days to pay off the balance.  Clientele and orders began to increase.  With satisfaction, Betty says that today she helps her husband with family costs, without neglecting her duties as mother and wife because her business does not take up all of her time.  Her profit margin from this activity is 38%, on average.

This is Betty's first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, to be invested in the purchase of clothes for men, women, and children and for footwear, perfume and women’s accessories.  Because it is close to the December season, orders have increased substantially.  As time passes, this micro-entrepreneur has been able to establish a good client base and has separated from those that are delinquent.  In the not so distant future, she dreams of opening a store where she can offer all of her products and more comfortably attend to all that visit.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for men, women and children, footwear, perfumes and women's accessories.

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg J. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own apartment. Her younger son attends high school and her husband operates a taxi service, using his own car, to supplement the family income. 

Altantsetseg operates a car-repair and service business with three other business partners. She began her business in 1998, repairing a variety of cars' bodies in the local market, and has since gained significant experience as a wheelwright. 

Today, she and her business partners work together in their shop to provide a car-repair service to their customers. Their daily business income has reached 100000 MNT. Altantsetseg is responsible for painting the cars' bodies. 

For the future, she hopes to continue operating her business with stable operation. She is a very friendly and hard-working woman and says, " I am planning to buy my own car." 

She is requesting a 1000000 MNT loan in order to purchase more materials and supplies for her car-repair business.

loans.use: To purchase more materials and supplies for her car-repair business

loans.name: Yvonne

texts.en: Yvonne is 29 years old. She is married and has three children who are in the range of six and ten years old. She owns a boutique of various items with her husband. She says that with this loan she will create another business selling charcoal and add more merchandise in her current business too. She is determined to improve her business by reinvesting any profits she makes. She dreams of having a prospering store in the future.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Leonarda Yamilet

texts.es: Leonarda se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general. Ella es una persona muy trabajadora y esta no es la primera vez que solicita créditos, ya que tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación León 2000.  Inicio ofreciendo pocos productos pero fueron los necesarios que sus clientes le solicitaban. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de calzado, perfumes, toallas y sabanas pues tiene ciertos pedidos debido a la temporada festiva.
texts.en: Leonarda sells general merchandise.  She is a very hard-working person.  This is not the first time she has asked for a loan, as she has spent a lot of time working with the León 2000 Foundation.  When she began her business, she offered only a few products, but they were the ones her customers needed.  Leonarda is asking for this loan to buy footwear, perfume, towels, and sheets because she has special orders due to the holiday season.

loans.use: Purchase of footwear, perfume, towels, and sheets

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en:
Vladimir is married with two sons: 20-year-old Dennis and 12-year-old Artyom. Vladimir lives in Kamenka, which is a predominantly agricultural region of Ukraine. He grows early spring vegetables in his greenhouses for further sale. Vladimir owns two greenhouses and a swinery. He has been working in the sphere of farming for 22 years. He has already invested about 150,000 Grivnyas in this enterprise. 

Vladimir is seeking a 15,000 Grivnya loan to purchase seeds and polyethylene film. He has recently purchased additional land and constructed another swine barn there. Currently, Vladimir is planning to finish building two more greenhouses for tomatoes at the property he owns. One of his personal goals is to help his children through college and give them a good start in life.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and polyethylene film

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses has a mixed farm in the outskirts of Kitale town in western Kenya that is currently producing milk which he sells to the local households. He has been in the farming business for four years and also runs a brick molding business to supplement his income.

He has requested a loan of 31,200Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the proceeds from the increased milk sales will enable him pay school fees for his children. In future, he would like to expand his farm to 5 acres to enable him to venture fully into dairy farming.

Moses is 33 years old and married with 4 children between 5 and one. Two of the children attend school.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Nargiza

texts.ru: Байкабилова Наргиза проживает в районе Шахритус. Ей 23 года. Она разведена, детей не имеет. Живет вместе с родителями. У нее среднее образование. Она зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Она в основном разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже два года. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота и корма.
texts.en: Nargiza B. lives in the Shahrituz region. She is 23 years old. She is divorced and does not have children. She lives with her parents. She has secondary education. Nargiza makes a living by breeding large cattle. She mainly breeds cattle for resale in the future. She has been in this business for two years. This loan is to buy large cattle and fodder.

loans.use: To buy large cattle and fodder

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a married woman who lives in Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari store, electronic reloading and a food vending business. Her husband Carlito, who is 49 years old, works as an electrician and plumber to earn his living. She has five children who are between 20 and 28 years old. Susan joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Susan has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 21,000 to use as funds for her business operations so that she can continue to save up for future household expenses and savings. Susan is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: To fund her business operations

loans.name: Mayte

texts.es:
La señora Mayte es socia del banco comunal Las Luchadoras, del Distrito de Campo Verde, Departamento de Ucayali, tiene 41 años de edad y tres hijos.
Es reingresarte en el banquito  y lleva 3 ciclos.  Mayte tiene una bodega que funciona en su propia casa, sus hijos la ayudan con la atención y su esposo se desempeña como maestro panadero.

Con su nuevo préstamo de S/. 2,000.00 nuevos soles comprará: 1 saco de arroz, 1 paquete de fideos, 1 saco de azúcar, 1 caja de aceite, 1 caja de lava vajillas, 1 caja de leche, 10 paquetes de papel higiénico, 1 paquete de fideos para sopa, 5 kilos de menestras, 2 kilos de chuño, 2 kilos de harina, 1 caja de conservas.

"Con Manuela Ramos las mujeres han aprendido que también pueden generar sus propios ingresos, para poder aportar a su hogar algo de dinero, no es mucho pero es de gran ayuda para sus esposos".
texts.en:
Mayte is a member of the "Las Luchadoras" community bank which is located in Campo Verde district, in Ucayli department.  She is 41 years old and has three children.

Mayte has rejoined her bank and been a member for 3 loan cycles.  She has a grocery store which is located in her own home.  Her children help her to serve her customers and her husband works as a master baker.

Mayte will use this new loan for 2,000 Peruvian soles to buy: 1 sack of rice, 1 pack of noodles, 1 sack of sugar, 1 crate of oil, 1 crate of dishwashing liquid, 1 crate of milk, 10 packs of toilet paper, 1 pack of soup noodles, 5 kilos of mixed veg, 2 kilos of 'chuño' (dried potato product), 2 kilos of flour and 1 crate of canned food.

"Through Manuela Ramos, women have learned that they can make their own income to help contribute money to their households.  It isn't much but it is a great help to their husbands".

loans.use: to buy milk, sugar, oil, mixed veg and canned food

loans.name: Marlene Jacqueline

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal La Sequita se reúne en La parroquia Sequita que pertenece a Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, su gente es muy trabajadora, dedicada a sus familias y muy orgullosa de sus raíces.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Marlene, tiene 21 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos de 4 y 2 años. El marido trabaja en una fábrica en Manta.

Ella trabaja con su papá que tiene un taller de ebanistería en el cual realizan una gran variedad de artículos con la madera como por ejemplo: camas, muebles, puertas, cajoneras, ventanas entre otras muchas obras. Trabajan todos los días desde las 8h00hasta las 16h00 y cuando tienen mucho trabajo hasta más tarde,  nos cuenta que hacen obras para particulares que llegan hasta su establecimiento y también entregan en un almacén en la ciudad de Portoviejo.
 
Este crédito es para comprar madera, pinturas, selladores, clavos, pega entre otros productos que se necesitan para fabricar sus productos. Está en el Banco Comunal hace tres años  y le gusta la facilidad para conseguir los créditos. 

Sus metas son seguir trabajando por el bienestar de sus hijos.
texts.en:
The community bank La Sequita meets in the parish of Sequita, in Montecristi canton in Manabi province.  Its people are very hard-working, dedicated to their families, and proud of their roots.

In this location, we find Marlene, who is 21 years old and lives in a common-law marriage in which she has two children who are 2 and 4 years old.  Her husband works in a factory in Manta.

She works with her father who has a carpentry workshop where they make a variety of items out of wood, for example: beds, furniture, doors, drawers, windows, and many more.  She works every day from 8:00am until 4:00pm, and when she has a lot of work, she works later.  They do work for people who come to their workshop and they also bring items to the department store in the city of Portoviejo.

This loan is to purchase wood, paint, sealants, nails, glues, and other things they need to manufacture their products.  She has been in the community bank for three years, and she likes how easy it is to get loans.

Her goal is to continue working for the well-being of her children.

loans.use: to purchase wood, paint, sealant, glue, and nails for a carpentry workshop.

loans.name: Talapsu Group

texts.en:
Marie C. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Marie was born in a place call Punthu, about 37 years ago. She is married to a teacher and the couple has 5 children, 3 of whom attend primary and secondary schools. 

For 15 years now, Marie has been selling sugar, kerosene, fire-wood, etc.  With the help of this loan, Marie and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. Marie will use her share of the loan to buy the above mentioned items in bulk to add to her current ones.

loans.use: to buy sugar, kerosene, fire-wood, etc., in bulk

loans.name: Edilberto

texts.en:
Edilberto is 52 years old, married, and has a 2-year-old child. Edilberto is a seaweed farmer. He has been engaged in this business for 6 years. He usually earns 5,000 PHP per month from this farming. He plans to use his loan to purchase straw and other materials for seaweed farming.

In the future, Edilberto hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase straw and other materials for seaweed farming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to provide motorcycle taxi maintenance and to cover personal expenses.

loans.name: Alda

texts.pt:
Natural do Distrito de Inharrime, Provincia de Inhambane, Sul de Moçambique, casada e maê de 6 filhos de idades entre 21 a 36 anos de idade, os dois mais novos que vivem com ela ainda continuam a estudar. Fez 6ª classe do antigo sistema de educação e naõ continuou devido a dificuldades financeiras. Vive na casa propria e sustenta um neto e sobrinho que vivem com ela. 

Saiu de Inharrime para Maputo com a sua familia ainda menor de idade, tem uma area agricola de cerca de 2 hectares onde com ajuda de um empregado produz horticolas ha mais de 10 anos. Neste trabalho consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa.

Nunca  teve emprestimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atraves de colegas que são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu quarto emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000mt com o qual pretende comprar insumos agricolas (sementes, fertelizantes, adubos e aumentar areas de produção) para aumentar a quantidade de sua produção. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 8.500.00mt,10.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt e foi para agro negocio.  

Compromete-se a pagar devidamente para aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos  empréstimos para aumentar as suas areas agricolas assim como apostar na construção.
texts.en:
Alda was born in Inharrime District, Inhambane Province in southern Mozambique. She is married and has 6 children between 21 and 36 years old. The two youngest, who live with her, still go to school. Alda finished 6th grade in the old educational system and did not continue because of financial difficulties. She lives in her own house and supports a grandson and a nephew who live with her.

She left Inharrime to move to Maputo with her family when she was still a child. Now she has a farm of about 2 hectares where she has been growing vegetables with the help of one employee for more than 10 years. Through this work she earns about 3,000 meticais per month, which she uses for household expenses.

Alda has never had loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through coworkers who are customers of this institution. This is Alda's fourth loan with Hluvuku, and she is asking for 20,000 meticais to buy farm supplies (seeds, fertilizer, compost, and increase her area of production) to increase the amount she grows. The earlier loans for 8,500.00 meticais,10,000.00 meticais and 15,000.00 meticais were for agribusiness.

She promises to pay off her loan on time so she can have other loans in the future. Alda intends to ask for more loans both to increase her farmland and to try to start some construction work.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies (seeds, fertilizer, compost and increase area of production)

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food business.

Susana has been in this business for 2 years. Susana also earns income from selling of vegetables.

Susana has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of loans from NWTF.  She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business

loans.name: Waridi

texts.en:
Waridi is a married woman with five children. Four of the children attend school; one is still too young. Waridi owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 10 years, Waridi has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She also earns income from her farming business. A major challenge for her is delayed payments by customers who purchase goods on credit. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

Waridi decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), she plans to purchase sacks of sugar, rice, beans, maize flour, and wheat flour.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar, rice, beans, maize flour, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a hardworking 47-year-old businesswoman. She is married and blessed with two school-going children aged 12 and 10. 

She has been operating a beauty salon for the last nine years. She has managed to retain her business through the support of Faulu Kenya. She wants in the next five years to have grown her business and attained financial stability. 

She wants a loan of 70,000 Kenyan shillings to buy hair oil, shampoo, and conditioners.

loans.use: To buy oil, shampoo, and hair conditioner

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is from the village of Koghoto, East Georgia. She is 59 years old. Mariam lives with her husband Otar and five children: three daughters (25, 24 and 22 years old) and two sons (20 and 21 years old).

Mariam has a small grocery store. She sells various grocery products. In addition, the family owns three milk cows. She uses milk for cheese and yogurt production, which are sold in her store. The average monthly income of the family is 1,200 Laris. It is enough only to cover the family's daily essential expenses. 

Mariam requested a loan for renovation of the kitchen, as it is in bad condition. After she pays back this loan, she plans to start renovation of other parts of the house in order to improve the living conditions for her big family.

loans.use: to purchase materials for kitchen renovation

loans.name: Luis Armando

texts.es:
En municipio de Managua, el señor Luis Armando  se ha caracterizado por ser un trabajador, se desempeña como ayudante de fontanero y se dedica a esta labor desde hace dos años. Es acompañado y con una personas a su cargo.

Actualmente ha acudido a ceprodel con el fin de solicitar un crédito para mejorar la condición de su vivienda en la compra de materiales de construcción  para hacer anexo de cocina, por medio de esta obra brindarle mejor condición de vida a su familia
texts.en:
In the municipality of Managua, Mr. Luis Armando is known for being a hard worker. He works as a plumbing assistant and has been doing so for two years. He is in a domestic partnership and cares for one child.

He approached CEPRODEL in order to request a loan for improving the conditions in his home. He will buy construction materials to build an annex onto the kitchen. This project will offer his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for expanding his kitchen

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca earns a living through farming. She helps her husband till their land, located in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Rice is the main crop that they grow to sell. According to Rebecca, they earn about 13,000 PHP per month from farming.  Rebecca's husband mainly manages their rice farm while she runs their sari-sari store business. She sells items like bread and canned goods.

Rebecca is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and herbicides. She hopes to own a bigger farm in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and herbicides

loans.name: Sam At

texts.en:
Sam At sells boiled corn. Her husband Kimseng is a construction worker. They live along National Road number five, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have two daughters who are attending school. 

Sam At is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 37 years old, married, and has three children.  She sells a variety of vegetables within her village. She has been engaged in this business for almost 18 years. Her husband is in charge of their rice fields and transportation business. 

Marites does not spend too much time selling her vegetables because she has a vegetable garden where she also takes her merchandise.  She enjoys her daily routine in cultivating her vegetable garden. Aside from selling vegetables, she is also engaged in the hog raising business, which she has been doing for three years. 

Marites is requesting a loan for 20,000 PHP, which she will use to buy additional seeds of squash, okra, string beans, and bitter gourds. This will have a great impact on her business because her profit will increase and her children will be able to finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase seeds of squash, okra, string beans, and bitter gourds for her vegetable backyard

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is 59 years old and sells generic medicines in her village. She has been a widow for about 18 years. Her husband passed when her youngest child was merely four years old. She has six children and is glad that some of them have their own good jobs that support their own families. Her youngest is now 22 years old and still lives with her. Josefina’s grandchildren inspire her every time she sees them and that keeps her working hard to expand her business. 

Josefina sells generic medicines in different villages near her place to generate a daily income to support her children's and grandchildren’s need. She is very proud that even though she is a widow, it has not been a hindrance for her to pursue working and provide financial support to her children. Josefina is requesting a loan of PHP 20,000, which will be used as her additional working capital in expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy medicine for her business.

loans.name: Luis

texts.es: El señor Luis con  su esposa se dedican a la venta de comida en una pensión, y además Luis es chofer de reemplazo en una compañía de radio taxis; con estas actividades cubre los gastos familiares. Con el dinero del crédito comprara insumos al por mayor como ser arroz, fideo, papas, chuño, etc., para el negocio de venta de comida. De esta manera sus costos son menores y por ende tiene posibilidad de mejorar sus ingresos. Vive en casa de anticrético en la ciudad de El Alto, es casado y  tiene tres  hijos.
texts.en:
Luis and his wife sell food at a boarding house.  Luis is also a substitute radio dispatch taxi driver.  These business activities cover the family’s expenses.

He will use the money from the loan to buy wholesale ingredients like rice, noodles, potatoes, and “chuño” (a Peruvian tuber), etc. for his business of selling food.  That way his costs will be less, and he consequently will have the possibility of improved income.

He lives in a house under an “anticrético” arrangement in the city of El Alto.  (Anticretico is a transaction not available in the U.S. whereby a property owner requests a "loan" from you in exchange for housing, which must be paid back to you at the end of your contract. If your loan is not repaid, the property owner loses the property to you).

He is married and has three children.

loans.use: to buy wholesale ingredients like noodles, rice, potatoes, and chuño (tuber), for the boarding house food service that his wife manages.

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en:
Bushra is a 40-year-old mother of two sons and three daughters. She used to sew clothes as a service for people until recently. She started in her free time. After delivering her orders, she made teddy bears for sale.

Using her connection through her existing customers and neighbors and through her children’s connections too, she was able to sell those teddy bears, which brought her new orders for new ones.

Now Bushra has applied for this loan to buy a new sewing machine and more material and fabric to make those teddy bears and create new stuffed toys too.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and more materials and fabric

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
This is Dolores, a 43-year-old resident of Pasay City, Philippines, who is married to Roger, an electrician, and the mother of three children. With assistance from her husband, she manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Dolores operates an LPG business, purchasing Liquefied Petroleum Gas tanks from wholesalers and then selling each at a small profit. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community, and she earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales everyday.

To help her continue business operations, Dolores is requesting a Php9,000 loan to buy more stocks of LPG tanks to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.

Dolores hopes her enterprise will grow more this coming year, and she dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of LPG products needed in her business.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is a farmer in Murang'a, Central Kenya. He is aged 23 and has been in farming for one year, with his horticultural produce being sold locally.

Wilson has requested a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a motorcycle for a venture into a transport business. He says he wants to do transport due to the boom experienced in the sector due to poor roads in the area and a lack of means among farmers to supply their produce to the market. He adds that it will also help secure him income during seasons of poor farm produce.

Wilson reiterates that fluctuation in market prices for farm produce during harvest is discouraging since they are forced to dispose of the produce as a result of a lack of a storage system.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married and blessed with five children who are in school. 

She has been running a cafeteria for the last ten years to support her family. She has employed three people to assist her in the business. She describes her business as busy since her potential customers are the local residents and passersby. 

Since Rose joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to access loans to boost her business. 

She is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to buy ingredients such as cooking fat, sugar and wheat flour. 

In the next five years, she plans to open another outlet of her business.

loans.use: To buy cooking fat, sugar and wheat flour.

loans.name: Liberathe

texts.en:
Liberathe is 35 years old and has five children, aged 8 to 18, all of whom attend school. She sells foodstuffs in a shop she has run for 14 years. 

Liberathe is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy peanuts, fish, onions, and cooking oil to sell in her shop. Liberathe will use any profits to renovate her house. She hopes to become a distributor of foodstuffs in the future.

loans.use: to purchase peanuts, fish, onions, and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Victor Alejandro

texts.es:
Víctor es un hombre de 23 años de edad, él es soltero y vive en casa de sus padres. En la actualidad el se encuentra estudiando para convertirse en Abogado, se encuentra en el octavo ciclo de la Universidad ULADECH, en Cañete, el cliente trabaja por la mañana como chofer, desde las 5 de la mañana hasta las 4 de la tarde, en la combi de su padre, esto le permite poder estudiar en las noches, desde las 6 de la tarde hasta las 10 de la noche. Él tiene una amplia experiencia en el negocio, debido a que empezó a conducir desde los 18 años, nos comenta que con ayuda de sus padres él puede continuar con su carrera y pagar sus estudios. 

Su sueño es poder acabar su carrera y graduarse como Abogado, y lo que más desea es poder titularse como magistrado y trabajar para ayudar a las personas que más lo necesitan. Su padre trabaja como contador en su casa, esta labor la dedica a las tiendas que se encuentran en Cañete, lugar donde vive y trabaja Víctor.

Con el apoyo de los prestatarios Kiva, Víctor podrá comprar algunos libros para su carrera tales como “Juicios”, “Nuevos codigos de procesos penales”, entre otros, los cuales están valorizados en S/. 150 a S/400. Estos libros son necesarios para que Víctor pueda continuar sus estudios, ya que desea ser mejor y demostrar que puede lograr lo que se propone, obtener buenas notas y así sus padres puedan sentirse orgullosos.
Víctor se siente muy feliz porque sus padres están siempre apoyándolo y confían en el, debido a que siempre ha obtenido buenas calificaciones desde muy pequeño en el colegio.
texts.en:
Víctor is 23 years old. He is single and lives in his parent’s house. He is currently studying to become a lawyer. He is in his eighth semester at the ULADECH University in Cañete. He works in the morning as a driver, from 5:00 in the morning until 4:00 in the afternoon, in his father’s van. This allows him to study in the evenings, from 6:00 in the evening until 10:00 at night. He has a lot of experience in the business because he started driving when he was 18 years old. He tells us that with his parent’s help he will continue with and pay for his studies.

His dream is to be able to finish his studies and graduate as a lawyer. What he most wants is to become a judge and work to help the people who need it most. His father works as an bookkeeper from home. He does this work for the stores in Cañete, which is where Víctor lives and works. 

With the help of Kiva’s lenders, Víctor could buy some books for his major, such as “Trials,” and “New Codes for Penal Processes,” among others, which cost between PEN 150.00 and 400.00. These books are necessary so that Víctor can continue with his studies. He wants to improve and show that he can achieve what he sets out to do and get good grades so that his parents can feel proud. Víctor feels very happy because his parents always support and trust in him, because he has always gotten good grades since he was very young.

loans.use: to buy books for university

loans.name: Na God Da Gee Group

texts.en:
Aminata is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Aminata was born in Magburaka town, about forty-five years ago. She is married and together she and her husband have four children.

For many years now, Aminata has been selling palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), cassava leaves, paper, etc. Aminata and her group members have applied for a loan of 1,000,000 Sierra Leonean Leones for each in order to improve on the size and quality of their respective businesses. 

Aminata is going to use her share of the loan to buy the above-mentioned items in bulk to add to her current stock. 


(Also included on the left of the photo is loan officer, Edna B. Konteh, handing over the loan amount to the borrowers.)

loans.use: to buy palm oil, cassava leaves, paper, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: San Miguel Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre San Miguel , se conformó en el  2.010, gracias a que una de las miembros invito a sus amigas y vecinas para la conformación del grupo  y  logró juntar a 18 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto en el 5º ciclo del programa de comité de mujeres de la fundación paraguaya.
Una de estas mujeres es la señora Celia, quien se dedica a la venta de chipas (alimento típico paraguayo) desde hace ya mucho tiempo. Comenta que siempre tiene buena venta, ya que haga frio o calor siempre es consumida, y eso le tae muy buenas ganancias. Su meta es poder seguir creciendo y de esa forma poder ayudar a su familia con los gastos del día a día.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de almidón, queso, manteca, anís y demás condimentos necesarios para la elaboración de la chipa que vende. Agradece a la fundación y a Kiva por la oportunidad que les está dando, a ella y a su grupo.
texts.en:
The Women's Committee called San Miguel ("Saint Michael") was formed in 2010 thanks to one of the members who invited her friends and neighbors to form the group.  Joining the group were 18 women, who can be found working very comfortably through the fifth semester of the program of the Women's Committee of the Fundación Paraguaya ("Paraguayan Foundation").

One of these women is Celia, who has worked selling chipas (a typical Paraguayan snack) for a very long time.  She says that she has always had good sales, as chipas are consumed regardless of whether it is cold or hot, and this results in very good earnings.  Her goal is to be able to continue growing, and in doing so, to help her family with their daily expenses.  

Celia requests this loan to purchase starch, cheese, lard, anise, and other necessary condiments to make the chipa that she sells.  She thanks the Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for the opportunity that they are giving to her and to her group.

loans.use: to buy starch, cheese, lard, anise, and other ingredients.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is married with two children. Rosemarie is 35 years old and lives in Caputol, Aloran Misamis Occidental, Philippines.

To earn a living, Rosemarie has a piggery. She has had this business for five years. Each month, she earns approximately PHP 3,000. Rosemarie has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, Rosemarie hopes to save more for her children education.

loans.use: to purchase piglets.

loans.name: Roseti

texts.en: Roseti is a 30-year old married farmer with four children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. She has been in the cocoa business for six years. She has a dream of renting many cocoa gardens to make a profit. She's so hardworking that only seasonal changes affect her business expectations. She is asking for a loan to buy cocoa to sell and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy cocoa and pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en: Merlyn is 49 years old and married with four children. Merlyn is from Calabayan, Ozamis City. Merlyn help her husband in farming activities. In 2007, Merlyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability and while waiting for the cropping  Merlyn engage in nail polishing. Merlyn is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase organic fertilizer for soil utilization. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Amah

texts.en:
Mrs Amah A. was born at Lome on April 2, 1968. Born to a poor family, she could not attend school. A courageous and enterprising woman. she raises four children alone since the death of her husband, five years ago. Her late husband, a jeweller did not leave an inheritance. Which makes life difficult for this poor woman. Known for rigor in all her acitivities, she successfully obtained a loan of $350 to relaunch her jewellery business. Honest and dynamic, she quickly wins the confidence of her clients who mainly come from Ghana and the Ivory Coast. With these strong customers she is not able to satisfy all of their demands because of the possible impacts on her household. Thus, she seeks a consistent source of income and to grow her business. Mrs Amah A. requests a loan of $900 which will serve to help her buy and resell jewellery. Financing this project today, will contribute to the well being of the family of Mrs Amah A..

Translated from French by Farron Blanc, a Kiva Volunteer

Madame A. Amah est née à Lomé le 02 Avril 1968. Issue d’une famille pauvre, elle n’a pas pu aller à l’école. Femme courageuse et très entreprenante, elle élève seule ses quatre (04) enfants depuis la mort de son mari il y a 5 ans. Son feu mari, bijoutier n’a rien laissé comme héritage. Ce qui rend pénible la tâche pour cette pauvre femme. Connue pour la rigueur dans ses activités, elle réussit à obtenir un crédit de $350 pour relancer le commerce de bijoux qu’elle faisait auparavant. Honnête et Dynamique, elle gagne rapidement la confiance des clients qui viennent pour la plupart de la Côte d’Ivoire et du Ghana. Avec cette forte clientèle, elle n’arrive pas à satisfaire à toutes les demandes car son fonds de commerce n’est pas considérable. Ce qui a des impacts sur son ménage. Elle recherche à ce jour un appui financier plus consistant pour agrandir son commerce. Madame A. Amah sollicite pour ce faire un crédit d’un montant de $900 qui va servir de fonds de commerce pour l’achat et la revente des bijoux. Financer ce projet aujourd’hui, c’est contribuer au bien-être de la famille de Madame A. Amah

loans.use: Buy and resell jewellery

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is married with three children, all in primary school. He completed his secondary schooling but has not undertaken any formal training.
